body.p:
Shortly after the date of
my last, 17th ult, I had the pleasure of re
ceiving your valued lines of 4th ult. I am hap
py to reply that during the last two months
peace has prevailed among us. Previously
we had enjoyed it between two and three
years, when unfortunately it was interrupt
ed, and a secular paper was made the vehi
cle for placing all the supposed grievances of
the congregation before the eyes of strangers.
Those really interested in the welfare of the
Jewish name left the claimants to reform
all the benefit thereof (if they could find any
in it) but when a new field was opened, thro'
the Jewish press, publishing such gross misstate
ments as would lead our brethren to believe
that the religious agitation now prevalent is
felt all over the world to be requisite for the

“promotion of devotion, order, and decorum” while
indeed the standard is of the people's own making
and has no connection whatever with the reli
gion of the Bible, it was necessary to controvert
the same three articles on the subject having
been sent to the Chronicle as you have doubt
less seen in a late number. When changes are
known to be proposed in the spirit of religion, I
have no doubt the present opponents would
be among the first to hail all improvements.
But I allude to these things confidentially.
It is generally my opinion that the least
said about them the better, if it can be helped,
for man's disposition seems often to have an
infatuation in favor of contradiction, and
the more opposition his inclinations meet with
the more strengthened they become whether for
good or for evil. At the present time, we are,
thank God, in the enjoyment of the great bles
sing of peace, and I sincerely hope that it may
long continue, and be a progressive one. About
Mr. S. I believe among us he has no friend
who would go to the trouble of speaking to him, which
would perhaps also be useless. Even when he made

a show of religion he was not a popular man,
notwithstanding his learning besides. Mr. Car
dose suggests that you should make known
thro' the Occident your sentiments regarding
his conduct in the disavowal oof his religion. Mr.
C. requested me also to offer his regards to you.

I have none of the plain Bibles of $2 ½ on
hand. Please send me by first opportunity a
Daily Prayer Book, good paper and elegantly
bound, with the name Mrs. David Piza.—Per
haps you will be pleased to learn that I hope
to enter the marriage state during next mo.
probably on Monday evening 12th Adar, the
young lady being a cousin of mine, Rachel
Piza. I was formerly one of those who ridiculed
the idea of Israelites so generally marrying their
own relatives, but it seems to be the happy fate
of Israel since their forefather of this name set
the example not to mention his predecessors.

Anticipating the pleasure of soon hear
ing from you again
I remain, Rev. and dear Sir,
